analyzeResult.content:
PHILIP MORRIS USA
INTER-OFFICE CORRESPONDENCE 120 PARK AVENUE, NEWYORK, NY 10017-5592
TO: Dave Beran
DATE: February 5, 1993
FROM: Natalie Ellis SUBJECT: Learning from Marlboro Medium Direct Mail Research
Dave, this responds to your questions about the implications of the findings from the attached study.
The first key finding is that an unusually low percentage of people even recalled receiving the program. No mailing problems were uncovered, so either the format of the mailing did not break through the mailbox clutter or the program audience was somehow different. The higher recall of the bulkier live product mailing strongly suggests the former. In most companies, test mailings of all direct mail pieces are conducted and only those that perform well are sent to a larger audience. The implication is that we could improve the performance of our direct mail programs by pre-testing them. At the least, we need to do more to make our mailings stand out so that they are not tossed unopened with the rest of the "junk mail".
The second key finding is that while including live product in a mailing significantly enhances brand awareness, trial and purchase rates, free product coupons perform no better than regular carton coupons. Given the lower cost and greater volume generating potential of carton coupons, they seems to be no reason to include free product coupons in future programs. A carton purchase would also generate better quality trial than a free two packs.
A third finding, related to the first, is that predicted coupon redemption is lower than anticipated. The implication of this is that if brand trusts these findings, money budgeted for coupon redemption for this program could be released for other uses. At this point, not enough effort has been made to model the accuracy of consumer research in predicting eventual coupon redemtion. I am in the process of gathering the data to begin this process. Actual redemption rates take almost a year to compile so research which could make a prediction about redemption two months after mailing would allow better budgeting.
2040885469

SUBJECT: Learning from Marlboro Medium Direct Mail Research
Dave, this responds to your questions about the implications of the findings from the

A third finding, related to the first, is that predicted coupon redemption is lower than

FROM: Natalie Ellis SUBJECT: Learning from Marlboro Medium Direct Mail Research
Dave, this responds to your questions about the implications of the findings from the attached study.

The first key finding is that an unusually low percentage of people even recalled receiving the program. No mailing problems were uncovered, so either the format of the mailing did not break through the mailbox clutter or the program audience was somehow different. The higher recall of the bulkier live product mailing strongly suggests the former. In most companies, test mailings of all direct mail pieces are conducted and only those that perform well are sent to a larger audience. The implication is that we could improve the performance of our direct mail programs by pre-testing them. At the least, we need to do more to make our mailings stand out so that they are not tossed unopened with the rest of the "junk mail".

The second key finding is that while including live product in a mailing significantly enhances brand awareness, trial and purchase rates, free product coupons perform no better than regular carton coupons. Given the lower cost and greater volume generating potential of carton coupons, they seems to be no reason to include free product coupons in future programs. A carton purchase would also generate better quality trial than a free two packs.

A third finding, related to the first, is that predicted coupon redemption is lower than anticipated. The implication of this is that if brand trusts these findings, money budgeted for coupon redemption for this program could be released for other uses. At this point, not enough effort has been made to model the accuracy of consumer research in predicting eventual coupon redemtion. I am in the process of gathering the data to begin this process. Actual redemption rates take almost a year to compile so research which could make a prediction about redemption two months after mailing would allow better budgeting.
